Everyone working remotely:

ZOOM monitors the activity on your computer and collects data on the programs running and captures which window you have focus on.

If you manage the calls, you can monitor what programs users on the call are running as well. It's fucked up.

You create the bricks of your piece in two hours. After the session you can fill in any gaps with "mortar" (research, quotes extra context).

It's easy to get lost in too much detail when writing. Don't make the mistake of adding mortar first. Start with bricks.

In my writing, I‚Äôve almost completely switched from ‚Äúyou‚Äù to ‚Äúwe‚Äù‚ÄîI find it more engaging.

Why is @stripe's API so good?

Teams debate the naming of each field, talk about trade-offs, and attempt to plan ahead for new features that may change the shape of the API.

We *take the time* to get it right, and individual engineers recognize the best design requires teamwork.

I also realized that the core of my discomfort at the time wasn‚Äôt that I don‚Äôt get paid enough ‚Äî but that I was *envious* of my colleagues and people in the industry who earn more. That was an uncomfortable realisation and I had to work through that mentally and let it go.

But in a week or so, I realized I prefer to know what my peers at the company make, and understand how that is affected by their level, location, performance, etc. It was nice getting a mental model for how that works, and seeing it‚Äôs somewhat consistent if you know the rules.

You don‚Äôt need a library to create a UI that uses a state machine.

Recipe:

1. Create a list of potential statuses (loading, saving, submitted, errored, etc.)

2. Declare a variable called ‚Äústatus‚Äù that holds the current status.

3. Code your UI using the ‚Äústatus‚Äù variable.

The Basics of Handwriting SVG Paths (Part 1):

<path d="M 40,20 L 180,280" />

M: Move the cursor to the following x,y coordinate without drawing anything

L: draw a straight Line from the previous coordinate to the following x,y coordinate

There's an interesting spectrum of app rendering out there that I don't think has been coherently integrated into a single pipeline yet:

static gen / server render / SSR+hydration / client-side rendering

Sites should be able to pick and choose a technique per page and component
